contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox prepared food | name = Zosui | image = [[File:Kinoko Zosui, at Restaurant Gusto (2012.02.26).jpg|250px]] | caption = Mushroom zosui | alternate_name = | country = [[Japan]] | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Soup]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Rice]], water | variations = | calories = | other = }} {{unreferenced|date=July 2008}} '''Zōsui''' (雑炊) is a [[Japan]]ese [[rice]] [[soup]] made from pre-cooked [[rice]] and water. [[Okayu]], which is a similar dish to Zosui, is rice cooked to a watery consistency. Zosui (which is also called ojiya, a name considered to have originated from the Spanish word [[Olla]]) and [[Okayu]], while similar, are two separate dishes. While the two dishes both contain rice, and both are traditionally eaten when people are feeling unwell, okayu is a kind of porridge (similar to oatmeal), while zosui is akin to a vegetable soup with lots of rice. Leftover soup from [[Nabemono|nabe]] is often re-used for zosui. Instead of rice, [[udon]] and [[ramen]] noodles are recent alternatives. {{Rice dishes}} {{Commonscat|Zosui}} [[Category:Japanese soups and stews]] [[Category:Japanese rice dishes]] {{Japan-cuisine-stub}}
